title: Gemini added AI help to MoPiX with little guidance
description: This research showcases Gemini's impressive ability to autonomously integrate an AI helper into the MoPiX 3 application. With minimal human guidance—primarily focused on refining output formatting—Gemini added 500 lines of code, significantly enhancing the app. A compelling example highlights Gemini's problem-solving prowess: when attempting to create a rotating clock hand, Gemini provided precise trigonometric equations to ensure the hand rotated correctly from its end, not its center. This demonstrates Gemini's potential as a sophisticated co-developer, offering expert-level guidance for complex programming challenges.

title: Exploring how Gemini can now do more than generate text and images
description: This research dives into Gemini's expanded capabilities, exploring its new ability to integrate tools like Google Maps, Google Search, and code execution beyond basic text and image generation. The author first created a "silly app" to test if these powerful APIs could be used to build web applications directly. Building on this success, a more practical "Eco-Journey CO2 Calculator" was developed. This innovative app utilizes Google Maps to map journey legs between two cities and Google Search to calculate CO2 emissions based on car type and even electricity production, demonstrating Gemini's potential for complex, real-world applications.

title: Playing etymology and history games with chatbots
description: Forget building apps – this research brilliantly explores turning chatbots themselves into dynamic educational games. Beginning with an etymology challenge, the author discovered that models like ChatGPT could swiftly generate multiple-choice questions for user-provided words, offering the real origin alongside plausible fakes, and even keep score. Buoyed by this success, the AI was then prompted to suggest further 'app-free' learning games, resulting in innovative ideas like 'First Lines Game,' 'Historical "Which Came First?"', and 'Invention Year Game.' This post reveals the exciting potential of leveraging existing chat interfaces for versatile, engaging, and instantly playable knowledge-based activities.

title: Creating Logo programs using free-form speech

videos.title: Talk to the Logo turtle demo
Talk to the Logo turtle demo

description: This research explores a novel approach to AI-assisted education, demonstrating how Gemini 2.5 Pro can be leveraged to create programming tools from natural language. Ken Kahn iteratively developed an app that understands free-form speech and generates Logo programs, moving from basic turtle graphics to a full interpreter. Through 79 detailed exchanges, Gemini refined its understanding and code generation, illustrating a powerful proof-of-concept where users can simply speak commands like "draw a red triangle" to instantly visualize Logo's output. This innovative method offers significant potential for making programming education more accessible and intuitive.

title: A Tarot Card app conceived and implemented by Gemini 3 Pro
description: This research vividly showcases Gemini 3 Pro's creative prowess, tasking the AI with conceiving and implementing novel web applications. The highlight is "The Zeitgeist Tarot," an app entirely envisioned by Gemini. This unique creation uses Gemini's Google Search Grounding to analyze the "live mood" surrounding any user-entered topic, from current events to broad concepts. It then summarizes this collective sentiment in three words, crafts a concise "fortune," and leverages Imagen to generate a personalized Tarot card, offering a compelling demonstration of LLM-driven digital art and real-time cultural interpretation.

title: Infinite Zoom conceived and implemented by Gemini 3 Pro

videos.title: Powers of Ten™ (1977)
Powers of Ten™ (1977)

description: Dive into "The Synesthetic Poet," an innovative app where Gemini 3 Pro transforms textual input into dynamic, abstract art. Users simply enter a poem or thought, and the app leverages the Gemini API, instructing it to act as an "expert P5.js creative coder." Gemini analyzes the text's sentiment, rhythm, and imagery, then generates a unique, runnable JavaScript function that instantly creates a visual representation on screen. This project showcases Gemini's remarkable capacity to not just generate ideas, but to write functional code that produces expressive, AI-driven generative art, moving beyond simple pixel generation into the realm of creative coding.

title: Self-Coding Art Blob - conceived and implemented by Gemini 3 Pro

videos.title: Self-Coding Art Blob Demo
Self-Coding Art Blob - live coding demo
Self-Coding Art Blob Demo
Self-Coding Art Blob - live coding demo

description: The "Self-Coding Art Blob," conceived and implemented by Gemini 3 Pro, presents a captivating exploration into AI-driven creativity. This experimental app features a "Living Blob" that dynamically morphs its behavior in real-time. Users simply type a descriptive word like "Spiky" or "Liquid," prompting the app to send its current P5.js `draw()` function to Gemini. Gemini then intelligently rewrites the function to incorporate the user's input, hot-swapping the logic live to instantly alter the blob's movement and shape. This innovative project demonstrates AI's capacity not only to generate novel app ideas but also to actively participate in their dynamic, self-modifying implementation.

title: Gemini proposes and implements ‘Magic SketchPad’ that turns sketches into simple animations

videos.title: Magic sketchpad demo
Magic sketchpad demo

description: This research unveils the creation of 'Magic SketchPad,' an innovative web app developed through prompting Gemini's generative AI. Users draw simple sketches on a canvas, then with a click of "Magic Animate," Gemini's API interprets the drawing and generates P5.js code. This code dynamically animates the sketch, transforming static lines into wriggling squiggles or circles into bouncing shapes. The resulting single-file HTML app offers a delightful, AI-powered experience, bringing user drawings to life with quirky, imaginative motion.

title: Gemini creating a Tetris-like game for foreign language practice

videos.title: WordFall demo - vocabulary practice in a tetris-like game
WordFall demo - vocabulary practice in a tetris-like game

description: This research showcases Gemini 2.5 Pro's impressive ability to rapidly create "WordFall," a unique Tetris-like game for foreign language practice. Players match falling blocks containing words from two different languages that share the same meaning, causing them to disintegrate. Starting from a high-level prompt, Gemini generated a nearly complete, working game, which was then extended to support any two languages and generate word lists based on user-defined categories like "food." This project highlights AI's remarkable capability in transforming abstract educational game concepts into functional, interactive tools, demonstrating its potential for innovative language learning applications.

title: Acquiring computational thinking skills together with a chatbot
description: This research explores an innovative approach to acquiring computational thinking skills, where the author roleplayed a high school student interacting with AI chatbots like Claude, ChatGPT, and Gemini. Bypassing complex programming syntax, the study focused on high-level concepts, with Claude notably providing encouraging questions and clear explanations. A highlight is the co-creation of a unique app designed to analyze natural language algorithms for constructing peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, offering a tangible and engaging way to grasp computational thinking through a practical, constructionist lens.

title: Co-creating an app for making a collage of generated images
description: Inspired by a 4-year-old's struggles creating image collages with AI-generated unicorns in Microsoft Paint, this research details the co-creation of a dedicated web app using Gemini. The app empowers users to describe images, then easily arrange and resize them into a collage. Impressively, a functional version was developed in just 11 exchanges with Gemini 2.5 Pro, and an even simpler app in only two exchanges with Gemini 2.5 Flash, highlighting AI's efficiency in app development. A key finding, however, revealed that hosting the app in a Gemini canvas for API-key-free generation prevented microphone access, posing a challenge for voice input.

title: Co-creating a multi speaker app
description: This research post details the fascinating co-creation of a multi-speaker text-to-speech web app, born from a desire to hear simulated conversations between AI pioneers like Minsky and Turing. Collaborating iteratively with Claude and Gemini, the project evolved from basic conversation extraction to sophisticated features allowing users to customize speaker pitch and rate, and even generate shareable audio URLs. Overcoming hurdles like browser voice inconsistencies and URL length limits, the app now intelligently attempts to match voices and links to external scripts. This exploration vividly demonstrates AI's power in rapid prototyping and iterative design, ultimately aiming to bring historical dialogues to life with dynamic, customizable audio experiences.

title: Chatbots are pretty good at making up believable words
description: This research explores the impressive linguistic creativity of AI chatbots, investigating how well they invent new, believable English words. Prompting ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini to coin ten "needed" words, complete with dictionary entries and usage examples, the author was genuinely impressed. ChatGPT offered gems like "glintwist" for a fleeting, shared unspoken thought, while Gemini conceived "Ambisway" for the awkward hallway shuffle. The experiment revealed the chatbots' remarkable capacity for linguistic innovation, confirming their ability to expand our vocabulary in surprisingly human-like and useful ways.

title: Chatbots helped me explore and understand “Contemplative Artificial Intelligence”
description: This research ingeniously flips the script on AI education, exploring how chatbots like Claude Sonnet 4 and Gemini can actively *test* a user's comprehension of complex scientific papers. Instead of merely answering questions, the user prompted the AI to inquire about "Contemplative Wisdom for Superalignment," a paper proposing principles like mindfulness and non-duality for AI design. This innovative, interactive dialogue, culminating in outputs like a "Contemplative AI Comparison Report," allowed the chatbots to provide detailed, constructive feedback, significantly deepening the user's understanding of how AI can embody contemplative wisdom for superalignment.

title: Exploring Pythagoras's Theorem with AI help

apps.title: ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)
ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)
ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)
ChatGPT - Pythagoras Intuition – Rearrangement Proof (interactive Svg)

description: This research post chronicles an ambitious journey to leverage AI in teaching Pythagoras's Theorem, focusing on intuitive understanding rather than mere recitation. The author extensively explored advanced AI models, including Claude Artifact, ChatGPT, and Gemini, with the primary goal of generating interactive SVG animations that visually demonstrate the theorem's famous rearrangement proof. Despite encountering numerous initial challenges and "laughable" AI outputs from text-to-video systems, the project details a persistent, iterative process of prompting and refining to coax AI into creating dynamic, visual explanations. It highlights the ongoing struggle and incremental progress in developing AI-assisted tools for deeper mathematical intuition.

title: Chatbots can build an app to “vibe code” micro:bits

videos.title: Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit
Using AI to collect and analyze data from a micro:bit

description: This research dives into the intriguing concept of "vibe coding" micro:bit computers, exploring whether AI chatbots can build web apps to create and debug their programs. While Gemini initially dismissed the idea, Claude successfully generated a proof-of-concept app capable of prompting for micro:bit code. This demonstrated the exciting potential of AI in crafting interactive hardware applications. However, a critical limitation emerged: neither AI-generated app environments could directly connect to USB-connected micro:bits, highlighting current permission boundaries in AI-driven hardware interaction.

title: Claude creates an app for visualizing acceleration data with commentary

videos.title: Acceleration visualizer with generated commentary
Acceleration visualizer with generated commentary

description: This research showcases the co-creation of an innovative web app using Claude 4.5, spearheaded by Ken Kahn. The app visualizes micro:bit acceleration data in an interactive 3D environment, offering features like smoothing and user-controlled rotation. Its standout capability is using the Claude API to generate insightful commentary and subtitles directly from the data analysis. This AI-powered analysis interprets complex gestures, such as horizontal, vertical, or circular movements, enriching the visualization with crucial context. The project vividly demonstrates AI's potential to quickly develop sophisticated, analytical tools for educational data exploration from simple prompts.

title: Five personas creating a musical app about Euclid’s primes proof

apps.title: Prime Number Imps in Mid‑Jig, Twirl, and Hop
Prime Number Imps in Mid‑Jig, Twirl, and Hop

description: This research explores a novel AI-driven creative process where five distinct personas, each with unique skills and personalities, collaborated to build a musical app about Euclid's proof of infinite primes. Acting as a team of "high school students," these AI entities were tasked with integrating images, animations, lyrics, and songs. The fascinating outcome, titled "Prime Number Imps in Mid-Jig, Twirl, and Hop," showcases the potential for AI teams to generate complex, multi-modal educational content, blending art, music, and programming into an engaging learning experience.

title: Disappointing chats despite improvements to Gemini multi-persona app
description: This research delves into the potential of multi-persona LLM apps for educational engagement, testing scenarios where AI characters collaborate. The exploration included elementary students creating stories with animal personas and recreating a historical debate between Aristotle, Galileo, and Newton on heliocentrism. Despite significant app improvements—such as enhanced image generation and chat tone settings—the resulting chats and story drafts were surprisingly "disappointing." Nevertheless, the experienced researcher remains optimistic that this innovative approach, with personas focusing on different creative aspects, holds great promise for collaborative learning and amplifying human creativity.

title: Using Claude to create Claude-powered apps
description: This research explores a groundbreaking method for creating AI-powered web applications using Claude's new "Artifacts" feature, significantly simplifying development by eliminating API key management and deployment complexities. The author successfully built an engaging SVG generator app that animates user input, causing shapes to grow and spin dynamically. While showcasing Claude's impressive ability to iterate on designs and add features like animation cycling, the project also uncovered challenges with its code editing capabilities for larger programs. This necessitated strategic debugging and simplification, offering valuable insights into both the power and practical limitations of using LLMs for accessible app creation and educational exploration.

title: A Claude app to converse with independent Claude personas
description: This research details the creation and exploration of an innovative Claude app designed to facilitate dynamic conversations between multiple independent AI personas. Users can define these personas, who then interact based on the evolving chat, unaware of each other's initial prompts, with the option for user intervention. The project successfully integrated advanced features like rendering persona-generated SVG images, replacing HTML output with interactive code buttons, and even attempting persona reactions to user-pasted images. While combining all ambitious functionalities into a single app challenged Claude 4 Sonnet due to context limitations, the work showcases significant progress in building rich, multi-AI conversational environments.

title: Updating the Connection Game Maker
description: "Updating the Connection Game Maker" chronicles the fascinating evolution of an AI-powered puzzle generator. Starting in 2023 with ChatGPT 4 to create New York Times-style Connections games (a game unknown to GPT at the time), the research details subsequent updates harnessing Gemini Nano, Gemini API, and Claude API. This exploration showcases how different large language models can be integrated into web apps for creative content generation. A key discovery allows for extensive puzzle customization via editable prompts, even enabling emoji-based games. The post offers a compelling look at AI's adaptability and the practicalities of multi-LLM app development.

title: Weird hybrid creature guessing game co-created with Gemini
description: This research details the fascinating process of co-creating a "weird hybrid creature guessing game" with Gemini Pro 2.5, leveraging its unique ability to combine image generation with conversational AI. Players are challenged to identify the two parent animals of imaginative cross-breeds, presented in a delightful 19th-century naturalist illustration style, complete with humorous responses and informative "field notes." The project iteratively refined the game, from overcoming Gemini's initial misunderstanding of its own image generation capabilities to adding features like guess limits and flexible answer recognition. It vividly demonstrates the potential of AI as a creative partner in game development, while also revealing practical challenges like image quality and API connection reliability.

title: Chatbots designing and making apps
description: This research, "Chatbots designing and making apps," explores the remarkable potential of AI to autonomously conceive and build web applications. Ken Kahn prompted chatbots like ChatGPT, Gemini, and Claude to generate "unusual fun web app" ideas and then implement them, acting solely as a critic and beta tester. This innovative experiment yielded 16 diverse applications, from the whimsical "Confetti Compliments App" and "Word Garden Flowers" to the imaginative "Constellation Composer" and "The Alchemist's Grimoire." The project strikingly demonstrates AI's emerging capacity for creative design and functional development, redefining the landscape of software creation.

title: A multi-persona app generating storybooks and comic books
description: This research details the creation of an innovative multi-persona app, powered by Gemini, designed to transform conversations into dynamic storybooks and comic books. Inspired by classic comic chat, the project began by porting a multi-agent conversation system to a Gemini Canvas app, leveraging its image generation capabilities. The core exploration involved prompting Gemini to visualize chat interactions as comic book panels, featuring cartoon speakers and their utterances. While initial attempts faced challenges with Gemini's tendency to embellish images with unwanted text and poor spelling, iterating through graphic novel and children's storybook styles progressively refined the output, demonstrating the potential for AI to create engaging visual narratives from dialogue.

title: Seven personas and me talking about creating an app for learning about numbers
description: This research explores an innovative approach to educational app design, simulating a "dream team" of seven AI personas, including luminaries like Jean Piaget and Seymour Papert. Tasked with collaboratively conceptualizing apps to help young children grasp the essence of numbers, these virtual experts engaged in 162 exchanges, each response enhanced by AI-generated "storybook" images. This fascinating multi-persona conversation ultimately led to the development of three working web app prototypes, offering unique insights into how diverse, simulated perspectives can shape pedagogical technology.

title: Playing Tic Tac Toe with a snarky AI

videos.title: Talking Tic Tac Toe
Talking Tic Tac Toe

description: Dive into the playful world of AI education with a research post detailing the creation of a "snarky" Tic-Tac-Toe AI. Starting with a perfect web-based game built via ChatGPT, the project quickly evolved by integrating Gemini to imbue the AI with a humorous, remark-making personality. The exploration further deepened by enabling speech recognition, allowing players to verbally interact with the AI, which dynamically responds to both game moves and spoken input. This engaging back-and-forth showcases the exciting potential of LLMs like Gemini and Claude in crafting interactive, character-driven experiences, even as the game was successfully ported across multiple platforms.

title: An app for exploring creativity in chatbots
description: Inspired by research on AI's impact on human creativity and collective diversity, this post details a fascinating exploration into Large Language Model (LLM) creativity. The author developed the "Gemini Response Explorer" and "Claude Artifact" apps to conduct 12 experiments with Gemini 2.5 Pro. These experiments meticulously varied temperature settings (0 to 1) and added specific prompts like "Be creative," revealing how such parameters influence the uniqueness of AI-generated content. The resulting data, beautifully visualized through an app created by Claude 3.7, offers crucial insights into fostering diverse and creative outputs from chatbots.

title: Gemini 2.0 Flash talking to itself
description: This intriguing research delves into the novel concept of having multiple instances of Google's Gemini 2.0 Flash AI "talk to itself." Capitalizing on the API's generous free tier, the author tasked an AI to build a serverless web page facilitating these multi-model conversations, initiated by user prompts. This unique setup led to a diverse range of creative outputs, including the collaborative design of whimsical animated apps like "Sentient Spoonful (Emoji Edition with Sound)"—a "soup game" imagined by an "Expert programmer" and an "Out-of-the-box thinker." Further explorations produced science fiction stories, creative writing lessons, and other engaging animated experiences, showcasing AI's potential for self-directed, collaborative creation.

title: Using “Reasoning” chatbots to improve the Connections Puzzle game generator
description: This research unveils a novel approach to significantly improve a Connections Puzzle game generator. Instead of solely refining prompts based on output, the author explored the "reasoning" capabilities of advanced chatbots like ChatGPT o1 and DeepSeek R1. By analyzing their internal chain of thought, critical misunderstandings and ambiguities in the original prompt became apparent, even when standard LLMs produced good results. Through iterative conversations, the project successfully clarified instructions for puzzle construction, leading to the development of a "pretty good" improved prompt that leverages a deeper understanding of AI's generative processes.

title: Chatbot-assisted co-creation of a neural net to judge confidence from text
description: This AI education research details the collaborative creation of neural networks designed to judge confidence from text, highlighting the evolving role of AI assistance in machine learning. Initially, a Snap! model was developed with a small dataset. Later, the project advanced significantly with ChatGPT's help, co-creating a web-based "Confidence Predictor" and, critically, enlarging the training dataset from 60 to 150 sentences with Claude 3.5, which dramatically improved model accuracy. The research powerfully demonstrates how large language models are invaluable partners in developing machine learning applications, offering crucial support in refining architecture and training for more effective outcomes.

title: Experiments with an app to repeat prompts to LLMs
description: This research unveils the "Repeating LLM Prompter," an AI-crafted application ingeniously designed to explore the iterative evolution of Large Language Model responses. The app feeds an LLM its own prior output, alongside a static prompt, allowing for continuous refinement. Experiments showcase remarkable transformations; for instance, a simple query like "To be, or not to be?" evolves over 23 iterations from basic rephrasing into a profoundly poetic, cosmic rumination on existence. This unique approach provides compelling insights into the creative potential and interpretive depth of LLMs when engaged in sustained, self-referential dialogue.

title: ChatGPT 4o creates a Chrome extension to find the contextual meaning of words on web pages
description: This research highlights ChatGPT 4o's remarkable ability to independently create a fully functional Chrome extension. Starting with a simple idea and Gemini Nano API documentation, the AI designed and coded an extension that accurately finds the contextual meaning of selected words on any webpage. The entire process, from initial concept to a refined working tool that runs locally and offline, was handled by ChatGPT 4o, generating every line of code. This innovative tool, accessible via a right-click, demonstrates how AI can rapidly translate a user's vision into practical, intelligent applications that enhance web browsing.

title: Playing chess by flipping between a ChatGPT tab and a chess app
description: Tired of manually copying moves to play chess with an AI? This research explores a seamless solution, detailing the creation of a custom web-based chess game, developed with ChatGPT 4o, that allows players to drag-and-drop pieces and displays moves in standard notation. The core innovation is a sophisticated Chrome extension, built through detailed prompts with Claude 3.5, which fully automates the transfer of chess moves between this custom app and a chatbot tab. This ingenious automation eliminates manual copy-pasting, offering a significantly enhanced, fluid, and integrated experience for playing chess against an AI.

title: Dialog and OceanAI responses and generated games by Claude 3
description: This research unveils a fascinating exploration into AI-powered education, demonstrating Claude 3.5 Sonnet's ability to guide non-technical students through web game development. Uniquely, the study prompted Claude to simulate two middle school students collaboratively creating and iteratively enhancing a simple environmental platformer called "EcoQuest." The outcome is a compelling, 24-page illustrated story, where Claude generated both the student-chatbot dialogues and evolving game versions, with ChatGPT 4o providing the visuals. This comprehensive narrative vividly showcases the iterative design process—from initial concept to refinement—entirely orchestrated by AI, underscoring its potential to democratize creative coding for novices.
